results.title: 6 Ex-Officers Plead Guilty to State Charges in Torture of Two Black Men
results.abstract: The former Rankin County, Miss., law enforcement officers pleaded guilty to state charges on Monday, less than two weeks after they entered guilty pleas to federal civil rights offenses.

media.caption: Hunter Elward, a former Rankin County sheriff’s deputy, in court in Brandon, Miss., on Monday. He and five other former officers pleaded guilty for their roles in a raid in which two Black men were brutalized.

results.adx_keywords: Art;Museums;Slavery (Historical);Black People;Restoration and Renovation;Archives and Records;Amans, Jacques (1801-88);Simien, Jeremy K;Metropolitan Museum of Art;New Orleans Museum of Art;Louisiana
results.title: ‘His Name Was Bélizaire’: Rare Portrait of Enslaved Child Arrives at the Met
results.abstract: The Met recently acquired “Bélizaire and the Frey Children,” a 19th-century Louisiana portrait with a secret: For over 100 years, the image of an enslaved youth was erased. This is his story.

media.caption: “Bélizaire and the Frey Children,” attributed to Jacques Amans, in the conservation studio at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It is a rare American portrait of a Black youth depicted with the white family of his enslaver. For many years, the painting featured only the white children; Bélizaire had been painted out.
media.copyright: Elliot deBruyn for The New York Times

results.title: Growing Segregation by Sex in Israel Raises Fears for Women’s Rights
results.abstract: Ultra-Orthodox members of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s far-right coalition want to expand the powers of all-male rabbinical courts, and to bar women and men from mixing in many public arenas.

media.caption: An ultra-Orthodox man walking past a sign in Bnei Brak, Israel, that urges men to not look at women in the street.
